11243Transition Metal ChemistryTransition Met Chem0340-42851572-901XSpringer NetherlandsDordrechts11243-010-9448-9944810.1007/s11243-010-9448-9ArticleSynthesis and crystal structures of two homo- and heteronuclear 1D nanochain coordination polymers constructed from Zn(II)/Co(II) with N-phosphonomethyl-1,3-thiazolidine-4-carboxylic acid ligandDengXiu-Jun1YuQing1ZhangXiu-Qing1BianHe-Dong1dLiangHong2grid.459584.10000000121960260College of Chemistry and Chemical EngineeringGuangxi Normal University541004Guilin, GuangxiPeople’s Republic of Chinagrid.459584.10000000121960260Key Laboratory for Chemistry and Molecular Engineering of Medicinal Resources, Ministry of Education of ChinaGuangxi Normal University541004GuilinPeople’s Republic of Chinagxnuchem312@yahoo.com.cn2412201032011362157161612201016112010612201024122010© Springer Science+Business Media B.V. 20102010Abstract

The homo- and heteronuclear ionic complexes, {[Zn6M(PMTA)6][M(H2O)4]2·xH2O}n [H3PMTA = N-phosphonomethyl-1,3-thiazolidine-4-carboxylic acid; M = Co, x = 10 (1); M = Zn, x = 8 (2)], have been synthesized by hydrothermal reactions. X-ray crystallographic analysis revealed that both complexes have similar topologies, in which nonanuclear [Zn6M(PMTA)6][M(H2O)4]2 cluster units are linked by syn-anti carboxylate groups to form one-dimensional nanochains.

Introduction

The chemistry of metal phosphonates has been an area of interest to both inorganic and materials chemists in recent years due to their potential applications in the areas of catalysis, ion exchange, proton conductivity, intercalation chemistry, photochemistry, and materials chemistry [1–8]. Furthermore, many microporous complexes have been prepared lately by the use of phosphonic acids with additional functional groups such as amino, hydroxyl, and carboxyl, which can increase the solubility of metal phosphonates [9–14]. Phosphonic acids with hydroxyl and carboxyl groups as ligands could provide many coordination modes, resulting in various interesting structures. It is well known that nanoscale materials often offer larger surface areas than those of solid or bulk forms, and a lot of interesting and new phenomena are associated with nanometer-sized structures [15–17]. The synthesis of one-dimensional nanostructures is of interest to explore their properties with a view of the construction of nanoscale devices [18–24]. Therefore, we have used N-phosphonomethyl-1,3-thiazolidine-4-carboxylic acid (H3PMTA) with a chiral carbon atom and three functional groups (amino, -COOH, and -PO3H2) as a ligand to synthesize two novel 1-D nanochain transition-metal amino-carboxylate-phosphonates, namely {[Zn6M(PMTA)6][M(H2O)4]2·xH2O}n [M = Co, x = 10 (1); M = Zn, x = 8 (2)]. Here, we report the synthesis, crystal structures, and fluorescence properties of these complexes. Complex 1 was further characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy.

Experimental

N-phosphonomethyl-1,3-thiazolidine-4-carboxylic acid (H3PMTA) was prepared by a Mannich-type reaction according to the literature method [25]. Other chemicals purchased were of reagent grade and used without further purification. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed with a Perkin-Elmer 240 Elemental Analyzer. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were carried out on a Thermo ESCALAB 250 spectrometer at room temperature. Photoluminescence measurements were conducted with a Horiba Jobin–Yvon FL3-TCSPC fluorescence spectrophotometer at room temperature.

Preparation of {[Zn<sub>6</sub>Co(PMTA)<sub>6</sub>][Co(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>4</sub>]<sub>2</sub>·10H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub>n</sub> (<bold>1)</bold>

Complex 1 was obtained by mixing H3PMTA (0.5 mmol), Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.5 mmol), Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.5 mmol), and 4,4′-bipyridine (0.5 mmol) in 15 mL of distilled water. The pH was adjusted to about 4 via the addition of 1 M NaOH solution, and the mixture was transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave (23 mL) and heated at 120 °C for 3 days. After slow cooling to room temperature, purple plate–shaped crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were isolated from the resulting solution. Elemental anal. Found for 1: C, 15.9; H, 3.7; N, 3.5; S, 8.9. Calcd: C, 16.1; H, 3.5; N, 3.8; S, 8.6. IR, (KBr,cm−1) υ: 3399.43 (s), 1620.59 (s), 1441.10 (w), 1407.92 (m), 1321.06 (w), 1258.13 (w), 1201.33 (w), 1122.75 (s), 1070.91 (s), 986.58(s), 944.13(w), 741.46(m), 561.51(m).

Preparation of {[Zn<sub>6</sub>Zn(PMTA)<sub>6</sub>][Zn(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>4</sub>]<sub>2</sub>·8H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub>n</sub> (<bold>2)</bold>

Complex 2 was synthesized by a similar method to that used for complex 1. Colorless plate–shaped crystals of 2 were collected when the metal salt was only Zn(NO3)2·6H2O. Elemental anal. found for 2: C, 15.9; H, 3.6; N, 3.5; S, 8.9. Calc: C, 16.2; H, 3.4; N, 3.8; S, 8.7. IR, (KBr,cm−1) υ: 3412.67 (s), 1620.26 (s), 1441.15 (w), 1407.16 (m), 1320.52 (w), 1251.88 (w), 1224.77 (w), 1123.60 (s), 1072.48 (s), 986.79 (s), 944.64 (w), 741.29(m), 561.11(m).

X-ray crystallography

A crystal of the complex was mounted on a glass fiber. Determinations of the unit cell and data collection were performed with Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) with a BRUKER SMART 1,000 diffractometer equipped with a CCD camera. The ω–φ scan technique was employed. The structures were solved primarily by the direct method followed by Fourier difference techniques and were refined by the full matrix least squares method. The computations were performed with the programs SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 [26, 27]. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms were set in calculated positions and refined as riding atoms with a common fixed isotropic thermal parameter. A summary of the crystal data of the complex is given in Table 1. Selected bond lengths and angles for 1–2 are listed in Table S1-S2.

Results and discussion

To determine the metal species and ratio in complex 1, XPS measurements were carried out. XPS confirmed the presence of Zn (2p3/2, 1021 eV) and Co (2p3/2, 781 and 2p1/2, 796.9 eV) in the ratio of 1:1.98 (see the Supporting Information, Fig. S1 and S2).

Single-crystal X-ray analysis revealed that complexes 1 and 2 both crystallize in the triclinic space group P–1, and they are isomorphous. The crystal structure of each complex consists of a nonanuclear cluster with a center of inversion and lattice water molecules. The nonanuclear cluster units can be considered to be constructed from the [Zn6M(PMTA)6]4− heptanuclear cluster which is further bonded with two [M(H2O)4]2+ units {M = Co (1); M = Zn (2)}. The homo-heptanuclear cluster in 2 is similar to those reported previously [28–31]. There are five kinds of crystallographically independent metal cations with three different coordination environments (Fig. 1). The central metal atom is located on a crystallographic inversion center and is octahedrally coordinated by six phosphonate oxygen atoms from six Zn(PMTA) chelating units, which are located at the middle layer. The neighboring atoms Zn1, Zn2, and Zn3 adopt the same kind of coordination mode, but with different bond lengths and angles. The NO4 geometry around the six Zn cations of the middle layer is intermediate between trigonal bipyramidal and square pyramidal (τ = 0.45) [32]. The outer metal atoms (M) are six coordinated by two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two different PMTA3− ligands in a bidentate bridging fashion and four aqua ligands in an octahedral geometry. The carboxylate groups link the outer metal atoms to form a 1D nanochain along the a axis with width of 17.345(6) Å (Fig. 2). The inter-atomic distances between the central metal atom M to the middle Zn atoms are in the range of 3.62–3.67 Å in 1, and 3.61–3.67 Å in 2, respectively (Fig. 3). The distances between the outer M atom and the neighboring Zn atom bridged by carboxylate groups are 5.42 and 5.67 Å in 1, and 5.34 and 5.72 Å in 2, respectively.

There are six independent carboxylate-phosphonate ligands, which adopt two different coordination modes (Scheme 1). One type of the ligand is pentadentate, chelating to a Zn atom with one N and two O atoms and bridging with two other Zn atoms and a M atom. This is similar to the coordination mode in other carboxylate-phosphonate heptanuclear cluster complexes reported previously (Scheme 1a) [28–31]. The other ligand is heptadentate, bridging to the fifth M atom through the carboxylate group by anti-syn modes as well as linking with three zinc and one M atoms (Scheme 1b).

Fluorescence properties

The solid-state luminescence properties of the free ligand H3PMTA and complexes 1 and 2 were investigated at room temperature. H3PMTA shows fluorescence in the solid state with a strong emission peak at 407 nm upon excitation at 331 nm (Fig. 4), which is mainly attributed to the intraligand π*- n transitions [33]. Complex 1 shows no emission in the visible region, which may be ascribed to the quenching effect of electron or energy transfer between the partially filled d orbitals on the Co2+ and the fluorophore [34]. The emission spectrum of the zinc(II) phosphonate, complex 2, exhibits a blue fluorescent emission band at λmax = 455 nm under excitation at 412 nm, as depicted in Fig. 5. The origin of the emission band of complex 2 may be assigned to emissions derived from ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). The lower intensities of the emission bands for 2 are probably due to quenching of the luminescent state by high-frequency vibrating water molecules [35].

Conclusion

In summary, we have successfully synthesized two new hybrids based on the new amino, -COOH, and -PO3H2 containing ligand N-phosphonomethyl-1,3-thiazolidine-4-carboxylic acid. The varied coordination modes of the ligand found in the present work prove that it is a useful building block in the preparation of novel hybrid frameworks.

Supplementary material

Supplementary material CCDC 682473 for 1 and 682476 for 2 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this article. These data can be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/.

The emission spectrum of the zinc(II) phosphonate, complex 2, exhibits a blue fluorescent emission band at λmax = 455 nm under excitation at 412 nm, as depicted in Fig. 5. The origin of the emission band of complex 2 may be assigned to emissions derived from ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). The lower intensities of the emission bands for 2 are probably due to quenching of the luminescent state by high-frequency vibrating water molecules [35].ConclusionIn summary, we have successfully synthesized two new hybrids based on the new amino, -COOH, and -PO3H2 containing ligand N-phosphonomethyl-1,3-thiazolidine-4-carboxylic acid. The varied coordination modes of the ligand found in the present work prove that it is a useful building block in the preparation of novel hybrid frameworks.Supplementary materialSupplementary material CCDC 682473 for 1 and 682476 for 2 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this article. elements.content: The homo- and heteronuclear ionic complexes, {[Zn6M(PMTA)6][M(H2O)4]2·xH2O}n [H3PMTA = N-phosphonomethyl-1,3-thiazolidine-4-carboxylic acid; M = Co, x = 10 (1); M = Zn, x = 8 (2)], have been synthesized by hydrothermal reactions. X-ray crystallographic analysis revealed that both complexes have similar topologies, in which nonanuclear [Zn6M(PMTA)6][M(H2O)4]2 cluster units are linked by syn-anti carboxylate groups to form one-dimensional nanochains.
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

The homo- and heteronuclear ionic complexes, {[Zn6M(PMTA)6][M(H2O)4]2⋅xH2O}n [H3PMTA = N-phosphonomethyl-1,3-thiazolidine-4-carboxylic acid; M = Co, x = 10 (1); M = Zn, x = 8 (2)], have been synthesized by hydrothermal reactions. X-ray crystallographic analysis revealed that both complexes have similar topologies, in which nonanuclear [Zn6M(PMTA)6][M(H2O)4]2 cluster units are linked by syn-anti carboxylate groups to form one-dimensional nanochains.

elements.content: The chemistry of metal phosphonates has been an area of interest to both inorganic and materials chemists in recent years due to their potential applications in the areas of catalysis, ion exchange, proton conductivity, intercalation chemistry, photochemistry, and materials chemistry [1–8]. Furthermore, many microporous complexes have been prepared lately by the use of phosphonic acids with additional functional groups such as amino, hydroxyl, and carboxyl, which can increase the solubility of metal phosphonates [9–14]. Phosphonic acids with hydroxyl and carboxyl groups as ligands could provide many coordination modes, resulting in various interesting structures. It is well known that nanoscale materials often offer larger surface areas than those of solid or bulk forms, and a lot of interesting and new phenomena are associated with nanometer-sized structures [15–17]. The synthesis of one-dimensional nanostructures is of interest to explore their properties with a view of the construction of nanoscale devices [18–24]. Therefore, we have used N-phosphonomethyl-1,3-thiazolidine-4-carboxylic acid (H3PMTA) with a chiral carbon atom and three functional groups (amino, -COOH, and -PO3H2) as a ligand to synthesize two novel 1-D nanochain transition-metal amino-carboxylate-phosphonates, namely {[Zn6M(PMTA)6][M(H2O)4]2·xH2O}n [M = Co, x = 10 (1); M = Zn, x = 8 (2)]. Here, we report the synthesis, crystal structures, and fluorescence properties of these complexes. Complex 1 was further characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The chemistry of metal phosphonates has been an area of interest to both inorganic and materials chemists in recent years due to their potential applications in the areas of catalysis, ion exchange, proton conductivity, intercalation chemistry, photochemistry, and materials chemistry [1-8]. Furthermore, many microporous complexes have been prepared lately by the use of phosphonic acids with additional functional groups such as amino, hydroxyl, and carboxyl, which can increase the solubility of metal phosphonates [9-14]. Phosphonic acids with hydroxyl and carboxyl groups as ligands could provide many coordination modes, resulting in various interesting structures. It is well known that nanoscale materials often offer larger surface areas than those of solid or bulk forms, and a lot of interesting and new phenomena are associated with nanometer-sized structures [15-17]. The synthesis of one-dimensional nanostructures is of interest to explore their properties with a view of the construction of nanoscale devices [18-24]. Therefore, we have used N-phosphonomethyl-1,3-thiazolidine-4-carboxylic acid (H3PMTA) with a chiral carbon atom and three functional groups (amino, -COOH, and -PO3H2) as a ligand to synthesize two novel 1-D nanochain transition-metal amino-carboxylate-phosphonates, namely {[Zn6M(PMTA)6][M(H2O)4]2⋅xH2O}n [M = Co, x = 10 (1); M = Zn, x = 8 (2)]. Here, we report the synthesis, crystal structures, and fluorescence properties of these complexes. Complex 1 was further characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy.

elements.content: N-phosphonomethyl-1,3-thiazolidine-4-carboxylic acid (H3PMTA) was prepared by a Mannich-type reaction according to the literature method [25]. Other chemicals purchased were of reagent grade and used without further purification. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed with a Perkin-Elmer 240 Elemental Analyzer. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were carried out on a Thermo ESCALAB 250 spectrometer at room temperature. Photoluminescence measurements were conducted with a Horiba Jobin–Yvon FL3-TCSPC fluorescence spectrophotometer at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

N-phosphonomethyl-1,3-thiazolidine-4-carboxylic acid (H3PMTA) was prepared by a Mannich-type reaction according to the literature method [25]. Other chemicals purchased were of reagent grade and used without further purification. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed with a Perkin-Elmer 240 Elemental Analyzer. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were carried out on a Thermo ESCALAB 250 spectrometer at room temperature. Photoluminescence measurements were conducted with a Horiba Jobin-Yvon FL3-TCSPC fluorescence spectrophotometer at room temperature.

elements.content: Complex 1 was obtained by mixing H3PMTA (0.5 mmol), Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.5 mmol), Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.5 mmol), and 4,4′-bipyridine (0.5 mmol) in 15 mL of distilled water. The pH was adjusted to about 4 via the addition of 1 M NaOH solution, and the mixture was transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave (23 mL) and heated at 120 °C for 3 days. After slow cooling to room temperature, purple plate–shaped crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were isolated from the resulting solution. Elemental anal. elements.content: A crystal of the complex was mounted on a glass fiber. Determinations of the unit cell and data collection were performed with Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) with a BRUKER SMART 1,000 diffractometer equipped with a CCD camera. The ω–φ scan technique was employed. The structures were solved primarily by the direct method followed by Fourier difference techniques and were refined by the full matrix least squares method. The computations were performed with the programs SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 [26, 27]. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms were set in calculated positions and refined as riding atoms with a common fixed isotropic thermal parameter. A summary of the crystal data of the complex is given in Table 1. Selected bond lengths and angles for 1–2 are listed in Table S1-S2.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography

A crystal of the complex was mounted on a glass fiber. Determinations of the unit cell and data collection were performed with Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) with a BRUKER SMART 1,000 diffractometer equipped with a CCD camera. The ω-φ scan technique was employed. The structures were solved primarily by the direct method followed by Fourier difference techniques and were refined by the full matrix least squares method. The computations were performed with the programs SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 [26, 27]. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms were set in calculated positions and refined as riding atoms with a common fixed isotropic thermal parameter. A summary of the crystal data of the complex is given in Table 1. Selected bond lengths and angles for 1-2 are listed in Table S1-S2.

To determine the metal species and ratio in complex 1, XPS measurements were carried out. XPS confirmed the presence of Zn (2p3/2, 1021 eV) and Co (2p3/2, 781 and 2p1/2, 796.9 eV) in the ratio of 1:1.98 (see the Supporting Information, Fig. S1 and S2).
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

To determine the metal species and ratio in complex 1, XPS measurements were carried out. XPS confirmed the presence of Zn (2p3/2, 1021 eV) and Co (2p3/2, 781 and 2p1/2, 796.9 eV) in the ratio of 1:1.98 (see the Supporting Information, Fig. S1 and S2).

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray analysis revealed that complexes 1 and 2 both crystallize in the triclinic space group P–1, and they are isomorphous. The crystal structure of each complex consists of a nonanuclear cluster with a center of inversion and lattice water molecules. The nonanuclear cluster units can be considered to be constructed from the [Zn6M(PMTA)6]4− heptanuclear cluster which is further bonded with two [M(H2O)4]2+ units {M = Co (1); M = Zn (2)}. The homo-heptanuclear cluster in 2 is similar to those reported previously [28–31]. There are five kinds of crystallographically independent metal cations with three different coordination environments (Fig. 1). The central metal atom is located on a crystallographic inversion center and is octahedrally coordinated by six phosphonate oxygen atoms from six Zn(PMTA) chelating units, which are located at the middle layer. The neighboring atoms Zn1, Zn2, and Zn3 adopt the same kind of coordination mode, but with different bond lengths and angles. The NO4 geometry around the six Zn cations of the middle layer is intermediate between trigonal bipyramidal and square pyramidal (τ = 0.45) [32]. The outer metal atoms (M) are six coordinated by two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two different PMTA3− ligands in a bidentate bridging fashion and four aqua ligands in an octahedral geometry. The carboxylate groups link the outer metal atoms to form a 1D nanochain along the a axis with width of 17.345(6) Å (Fig. 2). The inter-atomic distances between the central metal atom M to the middle Zn atoms are in the range of 3.62–3.67 Å in 1, and 3.61–3.67 Å in 2, respectively (Fig. 3). The distances between the outer M atom and the neighboring Zn atom bridged by carboxylate groups are 5.42 and 5.67 Å in 1, and 5.34 and 5.72 Å in 2, respectively.

The nonanuclear cluster units can be considered to be constructed from the [Zn6M(PMTA)6]4- heptanuclear cluster which is further bonded with two [M(H2O)4]2+ units {M = Co (1); M = Zn (2)}. The homo-heptanuclear cluster in 2 is similar to those reported previously [28-31]. There are five kinds of crystallographically independent metal cations with three different coordination environments (Fig. 1). The central metal atom is located on a crystallographic inversion center and is octahedrally coordinated by six phosphonate oxygen atoms from six Zn(PMTA) chelating units, which are located at the middle layer. The neighboring atoms Zn1, Zn2, and Zn3 adopt the same kind of coordination mode, but with different bond lengths and angles. The NO4 geometry around the six Zn cations of the middle layer is intermediate between trigonal bipyramidal and square pyramidal (τ = 0.45) [32]. The outer metal atoms (M) are six coordinated by two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two different PMTA3- ligands in a bidentate bridging fashion and four aqua ligands in an octahedral geometry. The carboxylate groups link the outer metal atoms to form a 1D nanochain along the a axis with width of 17.345(6) Å (Fig. 2). The inter-atomic distances between the central metal atom M to the middle Zn atoms are in the range of 3.62-3.67 Å in 1, and 3.61-3.67 Å in 2, respectively (Fig. 3). The distances between the outer M atom and the neighboring Zn atom bridged by carboxylate groups are 5.42 and 5.67 Å in 1, and 5.34 and 5.72 Å in 2, respectively.

elements.content: There are six independent carboxylate-phosphonate ligands, which adopt two different coordination modes (Scheme 1). One type of the ligand is pentadentate, chelating to a Zn atom with one N and two O atoms and bridging with two other Zn atoms and a M atom. This is similar to the coordination mode in other carboxylate-phosphonate heptanuclear cluster complexes reported previously (Scheme 1a) [28–31]. The other ligand is heptadentate, bridging to the fifth M atom through the carboxylate group by anti-syn modes as well as linking with three zinc and one M atoms (Scheme 1b).

The other ligand is heptadentate, bridging to the fifth M atom through the carboxylate group by anti-syn modes as well as linking with three zinc and one M atoms (Scheme 1b).

elements.content: The solid-state luminescence properties of the free ligand H3PMTA and complexes 1 and 2 were investigated at room temperature. H3PMTA shows fluorescence in the solid state with a strong emission peak at 407 nm upon excitation at 331 nm (Fig. 4), which is mainly attributed to the intraligand π*- n transitions [33]. Complex 1 shows no emission in the visible region, which may be ascribed to the quenching effect of electron or energy transfer between the partially filled d orbitals on the Co2+ and the fluorophore [34]. The emission spectrum of the zinc(II) phosphonate, complex 2, exhibits a blue fluorescent emission band at λmax = 455 nm under excitation at 412 nm, as depicted in Fig. 5. The origin of the emission band of complex 2 may be assigned to emissions derived from ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). The lower intensities of the emission bands for 2 are probably due to quenching of the luminescent state by high-frequency vibrating water molecules [35].
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence properties

The solid-state luminescence properties of the free ligand H3PMTA and complexes 1 and 2 were investigated at room temperature. H3PMTA shows fluorescence in the solid state with a strong emission peak at 407 nm upon excitation at 331 nm (Fig. 4), which is mainly attributed to the intraligand π*- n transitions [33]. Complex 1 shows no emission in the visible region, which may be ascribed to the quenching effect of electron or energy transfer between the partially filled d orbitals on the Co2+ and the fluorophore [34]. The emission spectrum of the zinc(II) phosphonate, complex 2, exhibits a blue fluorescent emission band at λmax = 455 nm under excitation at 412 nm, as depicted in Fig. 5. The origin of the emission band of complex 2 may be assigned to emissions derived from ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). The lower intensities of the emission bands for 2 are probably due to quenching of the luminescent state by high-frequency vibrating water molecules [35].

The varied coordination modes of the ligand found in the present work prove that it is a useful building block in the preparation of novel hybrid frameworks.

Conclusion

In summary, we have successfully synthesized two new hybrids based on the new amino, -COOH, and -PO3H2 containing ligand N-phosphonomethyl-1,3-thiazolidine-4-carboxylic acid. The varied coordination modes of the ligand found in the present work prove that it is a useful building block in the preparation of novel hybrid frameworks.

cln_elements.content:
Complex 1 was obtained by mixing H3PMTA (0.5 mmol), Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.5 mmol), Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.5 mmol), and 4,4′-bipyridine (0.5 mmol) in 15 mL of distilled water. The pH was adjusted to about 4 via the addition of 1 M NaOH solution, and the mixture was transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave (23 mL) and heated at 120 °C for 3 days. After slow cooling to room temperature, purple plate–shaped crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were isolated from the resulting solution. Elemental anal. Found for 1: C, 15.9; H, 3.7; N, 3.5; S, 8.9. Calcd: C, 16.1; H, 3.5; N, 3.8; S, 8.6. IR, (KBr,cm−1) υ: 3399.43 (s), 1620.59 (s), 1441.10 (w), 1407.92 (m), 1321.06 (w), 1258.13 (w), 1201.33 (w), 1122.75 (s), 1070.91 (s), 986.58(s), 944.13(w), 741.46(m), 561.51(m).

Preparation of {[Zn<sub>6</sub>Zn(PMTA)<sub>6</sub>][Zn(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>4</sub>]<sub>2</sub>·8H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub>n</sub> (<bold>2)</bold>

Complex 2 was synthesized by a similar method to that used for complex 1. Colorless plate–shaped crystals of 2 were collected when the metal salt was only Zn(NO3)2·6H2O. Elemental anal. found for 2: C, 15.9; H, 3.6; N, 3.5; S, 8.9. Calc: C, 16.2; H, 3.4; N, 3.8; S, 8.7. IR, (KBr,cm−1) υ: 3412.67 (s), 1620.26 (s), 1441.15 (w), 1407.16 (m), 1320.52 (w), 1251.88 (w), 1224.77 (w), 1123.60 (s), 1072.48 (s), 986.79 (s), 944.64 (w), 741.29(m), 561.11(m).

Preparation of {[Zn6Co(PMTA)6][Co(H2O)4]2⋅10H2O}n (1)

Complex 1 was obtained by mixing H3PMTA (0.5 mmol), Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.5 mmol), Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.5 mmol), and 4,4'-bipyridine (0.5 mmol) in 15 mL of distilled water. The pH was adjusted to about 4 via the addition of  1 M NaOH solution, and the mixture was transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave (23 mL) and heated at 120 °C for 3 days. After slow cooling to room temperature, purple plate-shaped crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were isolated from the resulting solution. Elemental anal. Found for 1: C, 15.9; H, 3.7; N, 3.5; S, 8.9. Calcd: C, 16.1; H, 3.5; N, 3.8; S, 8.6. IR, (KBr,cm-1) υ: 3399.43 (s), 1620.59 (s), 1441.10 (w), 1407.92 (m), 1321.06 (w), 1258.13 (w), 1201.33 (w), 1122.75 (s), 1070.91 (s), 986.58(s), 944.13(w), 741.46(m), 561.51(m).

Preparation of {[Zn6Zn(PMTA)6][Zn(H2O)4]2⋅8H2O}n (2)

Complex 2 was synthesized by a similar method to that used for complex 1. Colorless plate-shaped crystals of 2 were collected when the metal salt was only Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O. Elemental anal. found for 2: C, 15.9; H, 3.6; N, 3.5; S, 8.9. Calc: C, 16.2; H, 3.4; N, 3.8; S, 8.7. IR, (KBr,cm-1) υ: 3412.67 (s), 1620.26 (s), 1441.15 (w), 1407.16 (m), 1320.52 (w), 1251.88 (w), 1224.77 (w), 1123.60 (s), 1072.48 (s), 986.79 (s), 944.64 (w), 741.29(m), 561.11(m).

cln_elements.content: The solid-state luminescence properties of the free ligand H3PMTA and complexes 1 and 2 were investigated at room temperature. H3PMTA shows fluorescence in the solid state with a strong emission peak at 407 nm upon excitation at 331 nm (Fig. 4), which is mainly attributed to the intraligand π*- n transitions [33]. Complex 1 shows no emission in the visible region, which may be ascribed to the quenching effect of electron or energy transfer between the partially filled d orbitals on the Co2+ and the fluorophore [34]. The emission spectrum of the zinc(II) phosphonate, complex 2, exhibits a blue fluorescent emission band at λmax = 455 nm under excitation at 412 nm, as depicted in Fig. 5. The origin of the emission band of complex 2 may be assigned to emissions derived from ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). The lower intensities of the emission bands for 2 are probably due to quenching of the luminescent state by high-frequency vibrating water molecules [35].
cln_elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence properties

The solid-state luminescence properties of the free ligand H3PMTA and complexes 1 and 2 were investigated at room temperature. H3PMTA shows fluorescence in the solid state with a strong emission peak at 407 nm upon excitation at 331 nm (Fig. 4), which is mainly attributed to the intraligand π*- n transitions [33]. Complex 1 shows no emission in the visible region, which may be ascribed to the quenching effect of electron or energy transfer between the partially filled d orbitals on the Co2+ and the fluorophore [34]. The emission spectrum of the zinc(II) phosphonate, complex 2, exhibits a blue fluorescent emission band at λmax = 455 nm under excitation at 412 nm, as depicted in Fig. 5. The origin of the emission band of complex 2 may be assigned to emissions derived from ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). The lower intensities of the emission bands for 2 are probably due to quenching of the luminescent state by high-frequency vibrating water molecules [35].
